title: Fintech: how to fail so badly there will be wikipedia page about you
description: What to avoid at all cost with real case examples

cover_slide_data.heading: Worst Practice

published_attributes.title: Learning Plan
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Reasoning

It's best to learn from someone else mistakes. This course is overview if mistakes you can make with Fintech project that would lead to disaster of biblical proportions. Beside theory you will learn real case disasters originated from those mistakes.

Keep in mind those cases are relevant to most of our Fintech customers

E-learning outcomes:

Understanding of:

  • What are some of the most terrible mistakes you can make while working with Fintech projects
  • The real case outcomes of those mistakes
  • How to avoid those mistakes

published_attributes.title: Client that intentionally do not follow regulations
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• It is common that clients are focused rather on short time to market than understanding all regulations related to the business
  • This tendency is much stronger when it comes to Fintechs. After all the base ground of those is to rebel, trick and outsmart traditional institutions. This approach usually stands in contradiction to willingness to follow rules tailored for old, traditional, non-fintech institutions.
  • As global technology disruptor Netguru have significant impact on executing those ideas, nevertheless you have to remember it never exempts us or the client from complying with the law

blocks.text: It is common that clients are focused rather on short time to market than understanding all regulations related to the business

As global technology disruptor Netguru have significant impact on executing those ideas, nevertheless you have to remember it never exempts us or the client from complying with the law

published_attributes.title: Client that intentionally do not follow regulations
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Example: Enron Scandal

  • Enron's leadership fooled regulators with fake holdings and off-the-books accounting practices.
  • Enron used special purpose vehicles (SPVs), or special purposes entities (SPEs), to hide its mountains of debt and toxic assets from investors and creditors
  • The price of Enron's shares went from $90.75 at its peak to $0.26 at bankruptcy.
  • The company paid its creditors more than $21.7 billion from 2004 to 2011.

blocks.text: Example: Enron Scandal
Enron's leadership fooled regulators with fake holdings and off-the-books accounting practices.
Enron used special purpose vehicles (SPVs), or special purposes entities (SPEs), to hide its mountains of debt and toxic assets from investors and creditors
The price of Enron's shares went from $90.75 at its peak to $0.26 at bankruptcy.
The company paid its creditors more than $21.7 billion from 2004 to 2011.

published_attributes.title: Client that intentionally do not follow regulations
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Outcome for business partner - consulting company Arthur Andersen

  • Arthur Andersen use to be among 5 biggest consulting corporations in the world pwc, Deloitte, Ernst & Young, and KPMG
  • Company was found guilty of obstructing justice as a result of ‘looking other way’ when asked by Enron
  • As a result worldwide corporations was annihilated (including all of local offices in the world)

blocks.text: Outcome for business partner - consulting company Arthur Andersen

As a result worldwide corporations was annihilated (including all of local offices in the world)

published_attributes.title: Money transactions flows are not tight synchronised with database
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Whenever it comes to managing process where money are being transferred, you should be extremely cautious.
  • In most cases mistakes related to money transfer management can be multiplied or extending.
  • Most common example would be situation where:
    • Our application allows users to send money for example by sending request of transfer to external partner specialised in that kind of services.
    • The application has as error in data flow, it send approval of transaction ordered by user, before checking balance in internal database or before blocking user money in this database (in banking this kind of databases with related handlers and models are called Core Banking Solutions)
    • user can find a loophole and send multiple money transfers before our application recognise there is no money to cover those transactions
  • In modern financial reality where billions of transactions are made every second, it takes only a moment to use exploit that kind of mistake so hard that our client would loose all funds

blocks.text: Whenever it comes to managing process where money are being transferred, you should be extremely cautious.
In most cases mistakes related to money transfer management can be multiplied or extending.

user can find a loophole and send multiple money transfers before our application recognise there is no money to cover those transactions
In modern financial reality where billions of transactions are made every second, it takes only a moment to use exploit that kind of mistake so hard that our client would loose all funds

published_attributes.title: Money transactions flows are not tight synchronised with database
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Example: ART B and Economic oscillator

  • Art B representative ordered a bank transfer with physical presence at the bank office, and the bank clerk issued the transfer request to the interbank network and sent a paper note to block cash equivalent at client balance. There was significant time duration between ordering transaction and account blockade
  • Art B representatives rushed to the next bank office and ordered the same transaction even though they already transferred all their cash. This office dine have information about blockade and issued next transfer
  • Operation was multiplied to maximum
  • At the end of a day bank recognised that they send money that client didn’t have, they need to cover the cost from banks reserve and the clients are already in Tel Aviv with local citizenship (in Israel constitution there is absolute prohibition of allowing citizens extradition)

Bellow you will find the details of this swindle, however it is not required to watch the movie to complete the course. The movie is in polish but with english subtitles

published_attributes.title: Implement Fintech innovation without verification of regulations
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• While working with Fintech project you should never assume that customer have correct understanding of regulations.
  • We should always evaluate clients understandings of his product and legal framework he/she need to follow and/or take steps to separate Netguru from potential fines resulting from wrongdoing. Best case scenario both.
  • As you know from Fintech Fundamentals, different types of financial institutions have different rights, obligations, but also prohibitions

blocks.text: While working with Fintech project you should never assume that customer have correct understanding of regulations.

We should always evaluate clients understandings of his product and legal framework he/she need to follow and/or take steps to separate Netguru from potential fines resulting from wrongdoing. Best case scenario both.
As you know from Fintech Fundamentals, different types of financial institutions have different rights, obligations, but also prohibitions

published_attributes.title: Implement fintech innovation without verification of regulations
published_attributes.serialized_body:
For instance:

  • Lending Companies can not offer deposits to private individuals but on another hand it is company business that kind of scoring they implements
  • Banks can accumulate money for lending action by offering deposits. Nevertheless this special right is given under the condition that Financial Supervision Authority approves all banks policies to assure stability of bank. Even more the FSA can take absolute control over bank without court order in case of lack of those stability.
  • The people that controls the banks are great experts of current bankings, not the future technologies therefore you can forget about implementing Artificial Intelligence into Banks. Or at least until FSA management will educate them-self in advanced algorithms
  • BONUS: you can estimate dynamics in those changes by quick exercise - try to imagine the President of your National Central Bank analysing code with Artificial Intelligence algorithms

Lending Companies can not offer deposits to private individuals but on another hand it is company business that kind of scoring they implements

Banks can accumulate money for lending action by offering deposits. Nevertheless this special right is given under the condition that Financial Supervision Authority approves all banks policies to assure stability of bank. Even more the FSA can take absolute control over bank without court order in case of lack of those stability.

The people that controls the banks are great experts of current bankings, not the future technologies therefore you can forget about implementing Artificial Intelligence into Banks. Or at least until FSA management will educate them-self in advanced algorithms

published_attributes.title: Implement fintech innovation without verification of regulations
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Example: We implements super effective credit scoring based on Artificial Intelligence for Bank

  • Bank after implementations, start growth, our solution is perfect and management is super pleased by our work
  • Supervision authority is public institutions populated by government officials, there are not smarter than average of public institutions
  • Supervision authority demanded to present to them the logic behind the scoring algorithm. If we used a neural network (black box approach) there would be no method to present an actual algorithm. If our solution is indeed super cleaver the supervision representatives will not be capable of understanding the methodology. Either Way supervision will issue procedure of forced restructuring to reach back to previous state and most likely huge fine for client
  • BONUS: lending companies can use whatever scoring they want because bank lend the money they don’t own (clients money from deposits) and lending companies lend they own money

published_attributes.title: Fooling supervision by sophisticated algorithms and complicated technologies
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Sometimes Financial Supervision employees are not the smartest ones but at least they admit that
  • As the result those fantastic experts allows financial institutions to implements any kind of polity that is to hard for them to comprehend
  • We use opportunity and hire crazy scientists to tangle simple thinks the best they can. For example by proving that we can use excel it self to change risk securities into safe one
  • In the end we persuaded supervision authority that super smart people developed our algorithm form risk evaluation so without understanding they allowed to implement it

In the end we persuaded supervision authority that super smart people developed our algorithm form risk evaluation so without understanding they allowed to implement it

published_attributes.title: Fooling supervision by sophisticated algorithms and complicated technologies
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Example: subprime world financial crisis

  • Banks in US was offering mortgage loans to people that could not pay loan instalments (so called NINJAs - No Income No Job or Assets)
  • To gather more funds to issue more loans banks were trying to issue bonds secured by clients payments. But due to poor repayments no one was interested to invest.
  • Banks hired ‘nasa physicists’ to prepare magical algorithms. Based on them they ‘proved’ that if you mix expected payments from a big number of poor clients into one package we have AAA rating security (the safest possible). 
  • The supervision officials took their word and allowed it without understanding the algorithms. Long story short it seems that if we have a package of poor clients it is a poor package and magic algorithms don't work. 
  • Buyers of this bonds end up with nothing
  • Even though the ‘nasa physicists’ didn’t face any repercussions it is possible that next time provider of new magical algorithms will face at least huge fine

blocks.text: Example: subprime world financial crisis
Banks in US was offering mortgage loans to people that could not pay loan instalments (so called NINJAs - No Income No Job or Assets)
To gather more funds to issue more loans banks were trying to issue bonds secured by clients payments. But due to poor repayments no one was interested to invest.

Banks hired ‘nasa physicists’ to prepare magical algorithms. Based on them they ‘proved’ that if you mix expected payments from a big number of poor clients into one package we have AAA rating security (the safest possible).

The supervision officials took their word and allowed it without understanding the algorithms. Long story short it seems that if we have a package of poor clients it is a poor package and magic algorithms don't work.
Buyers of this bonds end up with nothing
Even though the ‘nasa physicists’ didn’t face any repercussions it is possible that next time provider of new magical algorithms will face at least huge fine

published_attributes.title: Assume fintech is always good investment
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• New fintech companies are no different to regular startups and in most cases will go bankrupt before changing market or generate actual income
  • On the other hand fintech that generate surprisingly high income should be monitored as well due to long list of fintech technologies that was created only as decoy for massive scam.

Example: Onecoin Cryptocurrency Scam

  • Onecoin suposed to be new BitCoin and safe investment for individual investors
  • Company lured clients by it sophisticated algorithms, in-house exchange mechanism and others 'tech revolutions'
  • In face OneCoin was massive Ponzi Scheme orchestrated to steal from investors
